questions.question: Unix command to change file permissions using numeric notation.
questions.explanation: chmod modifies read, write, and execute permissions.

questions.question: File system structure containing metadata about files.
questions.explanation: Inodes store information about files in Unix file systems.

questions.question: Link that creates a mirror entry in the file system pointing to the same data.
questions.explanation: Hard links create additional directory entries for the same file.

questions.question: Unix command to find files in a directory hierarchy.
questions.explanation: The find command searches for files based on various criteria.

questions.question: Process of marking storage space as available after file deletion.
questions.explanation: Garbage collection reclaims space from deleted or unused files.

questions.question: File allocation method storing files in non-contiguous blocks.
questions.explanation: Fragmentation occurs when files are split across scattered blocks.

questions.question: Table tracking free and used space on a disk.
questions.explanation: FAT is a file system method tracking cluster allocation.

questions.question: Unix permission notation using letters for read, write, execute.
questions.explanation: Symbolic notation uses r, w, x for permissions.

questions.question: Process of reorganizing disk data to improve access speed.
questions.explanation: Defragmentation consolidates fragmented files for better performance.

questions.question: Unix command to change file ownership.
questions.explanation: chown modifies the owner and group of files.
